> I think I must still be misunderstanding you...

Before I make a final release, my code is tested by other developers.
Those developers help me find the missing areas.

But keep in mind, if we have written a test for every conceivable
method we can come up with--someone, somewhere will have a situation
where something fails to behave as expected. Any time we have something
that does not behave as expected we have a failure or bug. Not behaving
as expected can be that it takes longer to process than expected, the
log entry doesn't have the information expected, or something more
serious.

I apply agile tactics to my testcases. That means I write what I need
when I need it. Just like we can get stuck in anlysis paralysis, we can
also get stuck in testing paralysis. I start out by testing what I need
to enforce. If there is something that can obviously be a sticking
point,
I will write a test for that.

However, what I am referring to with regression testing is that you
miss things. You find that something needs to be tested that you were
not aware needed to be tested. At that point, you write the testcase
that reproduces the error *before* you fix it.
